conclusion: Steel balls are released at 0.10 s intervals from the same point, accelerating down the incline.
Balls have uniform acceleration motions with the same acceleration along the slope.
Let the time that the top ball A has been moving be t seconds.
Ball B was released 0.10 s earlier, so its travel time is t + 0.10 s; ball C has been in motion t + 0.20 s.
With identical acceleration, the distance s a ball travels from its release point after time T is s = ½ a T².
Distances measured along the slope are related by AB = ½ a [(t + 0.10)² – t²] and BC = ½ a [(t + 0.20)² – (t + 0.10)²].
Substitute the measured lengths AB = 0.15 m, BC = 0.20 m and solve the equations for a and t.
Solving gives a ≈ 4.7 m/s² and t ≈ 0.17 s.
The acceleration of any of the balls along the incline is about 4.7 m/s².
The top-most ball A in the picture has been rolling for roughly 0.17 s when the photograph was taken.
